entries.title: ğŸ“ˆ What is Economics?
entries.description: The study of how societies use limited resources to produce valuable commodities and distribute them among different people.

entries.title: ğŸ“‰ What is Microeconomics?
entries.description: Focuses on individual decision-makers within an economyâ€”like households, workers, and businessesâ€”and how they interact in markets.

entries.title: ğŸ“Š What is Macroeconomics?
entries.description: Looks at the economy as a whole, including topics like inflation, unemployment, and economic growth.

entries.title: ğŸ“˜ What is Supply and Demand?
entries.description: Explains how prices and quantities of goods are determined in a market system based on consumer and producer behavior.

entries.title: ğŸ’¡ What is Opportunity Cost?
entries.description: The value of the next best alternative that is forgone when making a decision.

entries.title: ğŸ”® What is GDP?
entries.description: Gross Domestic Product measures the total value of goods and services produced in a country over a specific period.

entries.title: ğŸ§  What is Inflation?
entries.description: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reducing purchasing power.

entries.title: ğŸ“š What is Unemployment?
entries.description: Occurs when people who are willing and able to work cannot find a job.

entries.title: ğŸ’¸ What is Fiscal Policy?
entries.description: Government policy regarding taxation and spending to influence the economy.

entries.title: ğŸ›ï¸ What is Monetary Policy?
entries.description: Central bank actions, such as changing interest rates, to control the money supply and stabilize the economy.

entries.title: ğŸ’¬ What is Market Failure?
entries.description: When markets fail to allocate resources efficiently on their own, often justifying government intervention.

entries.title: ğŸ” What is Elasticity?
entries.description: Measures how much the quantity demanded or supplied of a good responds to a change in price.

entries.title: ğŸ§¾ What is Comparative Advantage?
entries.description: The ability of an entity to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another.

entries.title: ğŸ’¼ What is the Business Cycle?
entries.description: The periodic growth and decline in economic activity over time, including expansion, peak, recession, and recovery.

entries.title: ğŸŒ What is International Trade?
entries.description: The exchange of goods and services across national borders, and its effects on economies.

entries.title: ğŸ”§ What is Productivity?
entries.description: The amount of output produced per unit of input, often linked to technological progress and efficiency.

entries.title: ğŸ¦ What is a Central Bank?
entries.description: A national institution that manages currency, money supply, and interest rates, such as the Federal Reserve.

entries.title: ğŸŒ Impact of Global Events on Stocks
entries.description:
Global Events can dramatically shift market behavior, driving investor fear or enthusiasm, impacting valuations and capital flows across sectors and geographies.

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
- Stock markets are highly sensitive to external shocks and policy responses.
- Investors who anticipate or hedge against major events often outperform peers.
ğŸŒ Major Event Categories
- Geopolitical risks (war, conflict)
- Natural disasters (earthquakes, floods)
- Global health crises (pandemics)
- Central bank policies
- Political shifts (elections)
ğŸ¯ Use Case
- Investors track news, apply scenario analysis, or use event-driven strategies to mitigate risk or seize short-term alpha opportunities.
tags: impact of global events on stocks

entries.title: ğŸ’£ Geopolitical Tensions
entries.description:
Wars, military escalations, and diplomatic disputes introduce global uncertainty that rattles investor confidence.

ğŸ“‰ Impact
- Defense stocks may rise, while broader markets fall.
- Safe havens like gold or bonds attract inflows.
- Energy prices often spike (e.g., Russia-Ukraine conflict and oil).
ğŸ“° Example
- 2022 Russia-Ukraine war caused volatility in European markets and energy stocks.
ğŸ“ˆ Short-Term Effects
- Risk-off sentiment â†’ shift to safe haven assets (gold, bonds)
- Commodity prices (oil, wheat) spike
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Risk Management
- Diversify geographically
- Increase cash buffer during heightened tensions
ğŸ“˜ Reference
- Council on Foreign Relations â€“ Conflict Tracker

entries.title: ğŸŒ€ Natural Disasters
entries.description:
Earthquakes, floods, and wildfires can disrupt production, logistics, and regional economies.

ğŸŒ€ Economic Effects
- Insurance claims spike, utilities and infrastructure companies often impacted.
- Supply chains may suffer (e.g., Taiwan earthquakes and chip production delays).
ğŸ’¼ Sectors Affected
- Construction, commodities, retail (inventory damage), insurance.
ğŸ§­ Response Strategy
- Consider exposure to reinsurance and construction sectors.
- Evaluate disaster recovery funds or ESG impact themes.
ğŸ“š Case Study
- Japanâ€™s 2011 earthquake led to massive supply chain disruption in auto and electronics sectors.

entries.title: ğŸ¦  Pandemics and Health Crises
entries.description:
COVID-19 and other global pandemics introduce massive disruption across sectors, policy responses, and consumer behavior.

ğŸ’Š Economic Consequences
- GDP drops, unemployment spikes, supply/demand shocks.
- Acceleration of digital economy, remote work, e-commerce.
ğŸ’¼ Affected Sectors
- Healthcare (positive), airlines and hospitality (negative), tech (mixed).
ğŸ§  Investor Response
- Rotate into remote/tech stocks.
- Avoid high-contact businesses.
ğŸ“š Reference
- IMF and OECD pandemic economic impact reports.

entries.title: ğŸ’¼ Corporate Scandals and Governance
entries.description:
Major frauds, accounting irregularities, or executive misconduct can tank stock prices and raise market mistrust.

ğŸ’¥ Effects
- Stock price collapse, lawsuits, delisting risks.
- Industry-wide contagion (e.g., Enron, Wirecard).
ğŸ“ˆ Watch for
- Sudden CFO resignation.
- Short seller reports.
ğŸ§° Investor Tool
- Monitor whistleblower data, Glassdoor reviews, forensic accounting reports.
ğŸ“š Example
- Enron (2001), Luckin Coffee (2020)

entries.title: ğŸ¦ Central Bank Rate Decisions
entries.description:
Decisions on interest rates and monetary policy drive credit conditions, liquidity, and investor sentiment.

ğŸ“Š Market Impact
- Rising rates â†’ pressure on tech and growth stocks.
- Lower rates â†’ boost to housing, banks, equities.
ğŸ“† Events to Track
- FOMC meetings (Fed)
- ECB, BOJ, PBoC announcements
ğŸ’¡ Forward Guidance
- Language used by central banks can signal future policy shifts.
ğŸ“˜ Reference
- Federal Reserve Dot Plot and Summary of Economic Projections.

entries.title: ğŸ—³ï¸ Political Elections
entries.description:
Elections shift policy landscapes. Changes in tax, trade, or regulation can affect entire sectors.

ğŸ—ºï¸ Market Themes
- Defense spending under Republicans?
- Green energy push by Democrats?
ğŸ“ˆ Election Year Volatility
- Markets prefer predictable outcomes.
ğŸ“š Example
- 2020 US election impacted renewable energy, Big Tech regulation expectations.

entries.title: âš–ï¸ Regulatory Changes
entries.description:
New laws or enforcement actions can shift business models or introduce risk.

ğŸ§¾ Examples
- Antitrust investigations in tech (Google, Meta).
- SEC accounting rules (SPACs, crypto).
- EU privacy laws (GDPR).
ğŸ“‰ Market Response
- Sharp re-ratings when regulation surprises investors.
ğŸ“˜ Risk Monitoring
- Watch law proposals, FTC/DOJ investigations.

entries.title: â›½ Energy Crises and Oil Shocks
entries.description:
Supply chain disruptions, war, or policy limits on fossil fuels lead to oil price shocks.

ğŸ’¥ Sector Effects
- Energy stocks rise, airlines fall.
ğŸ“Š Inflationary Pressure
- Oil feeds into food, transport, manufacturing costs.
ğŸ“† Examples
- 1970s OPEC embargo
- 2022 Ukraine war and oil prices
ğŸ›¢ï¸ Hedge Strategy
- Commodities, energy ETFs, options.

entries.title: ğŸ’± Currency Crises
entries.description:
Rapid devaluation or speculative attacks destabilize economies and markets.

ğŸŒ Effects
- Debt defaults, import costs soar, central bank intervention.
ğŸ“‰ Investor Risk
- Emerging markets, currency-exposed corporates.
ğŸ“˜ Example
- Argentina 2018, Turkey 2021
ğŸ§  Monitoring
- FX reserves, bond yields, CDS spreads.

entries.title: ğŸ“° Media and Misinformation
entries.description:
Fake news, viral social posts, or rumors can rapidly shift market sentiment.

ğŸ’¡ Investor Caution
- Distinguish signal from noise.
ğŸ“‰ Example
- False tweet about White House explosion briefly crashed Dow in 2013.
ğŸ” Tools
- Use verified sources, sentiment monitoring tools.

entries.title: ğŸ¤– AI and Automation Shocks
entries.description:
Sudden advances in automation/AI (e.g., ChatGPT) cause sector disruption, investor euphoria or fear.

ğŸ“Š Market Reaction
- Rotation into AI winners (chips, software).
- Layoffs in exposed industries (support, media).
ğŸ§  Monitor
- Corporate AI investments
- Regulatory pushback
ğŸ“š Example
- Microsoft, Nvidia surge on AI narrative.

entries.title: ğŸ« What is Business School Courses?

Business School Courses provide structured education in economics, management, finance, and entrepreneurship.

- Undergraduate: Foundations of economics, management, and marketing

entries.description:
Undergraduate Business Courses form the academic backbone for future MBAs, entrepreneurs, and corporate leaders.

entries.title: ğŸ“¦ What is Macroeconomics?
entries.description:

        ğŸ“˜ Theory Sources
        - Keynesian Economics
        - Monetarism
        - IS-LM & AD-AS Models
        
        ğŸ’¡ Relevance

        - Political risk

entries.title: ğŸ“‰ What is Principles of Accounting?

Principles of Accounting teaches the systematic recording, reporting, and analysis of financial transactions.
        
        ğŸ“Š Concepts Covered

        ğŸ”— External Resources

entries.title: ğŸŒ What is Principles of Marketing?

entries.title: ğŸ§¾ What is Principles of Management?
entries.description:
Principles of Management explores how to plan, lead, organize, and control an organization to achieve goals efficiently.

        ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters

entries.title: ğŸ§® What is Financial Markets and Institutions?
entries.description:
Financial Markets and Institutions introduces how capital flows through various intermediaries and platforms that support the economy.
    
        ğŸ¦ Key Topics
        - Types of markets: equity, bond, derivatives, money
        - Role of institutions: banks, mutual funds, pension funds, central banks

        ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
        Financial markets allocate resources efficiently and impact investment, inflation, and employment.
    
        ğŸ“˜ Example Case
        How the 2008 global financial crisis exposed systemic risk in interbank lending markets.
    
        ğŸ”Š AI Summary
        Financial markets and institutions form the backbone of the economy by facilitating funding, investment, and liquidity.
    
        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Understand roles of key financial institutions
Study structure of capital and debt markets
Analyze interest rate impact on investment
Explore regulatory frameworks (e.g., Basel III)

entries.title: ğŸ” What is Operations Management?
entries.description:
Operations Management is the discipline of designing, managing, and improving production and service delivery processes.
    
        âš™ï¸ Key Themes
        - Supply chain design and logistics
        - Quality management (e.g., Six Sigma, TQM)
        - Lean systems and capacity planning
    
        ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
        Efficient operations improve customer satisfaction, reduce cost, and create competitive advantage.
    
        ğŸ“˜ Example Case
        Toyota Production System (TPS) as a model of just-in-time manufacturing and lean innovation.
    
        ğŸ”Š AI Summary
        Operations management ensures the smooth delivery of products and services while minimizing waste and maximizing value.
    
        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Map the production or service process
Identify inefficiencies or delays
Apply optimization techniques (e.g., lean, Six Sigma)
Monitor KPIs and continuously improve

entries.title: ğŸš€ What is Business Data Analytics?
entries.description:
Business Data Analytics is the use of data to make informed business decisions, uncover insights, and predict future outcomes.
    
        ğŸ“Š Tools & Techniques

        ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
        Data-driven decision-making improves performance and enables strategic planning.
    
        ğŸ“˜ Example Case
        How Target used customer data to predict pregnancy patterns and personalize marketing.
    
        ğŸ”Š AI Summary
        Business analytics empowers decision-makers with evidence, uncovering hidden patterns to drive performance.
    
        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Collect and clean relevant business data

Apply forecasting or modeling for predictions
Recommend actions using prescriptive tools

entries.title: ğŸª™ What is International Business?
entries.description:
International Business explores the strategies and challenges of operating across national borders.
    
        ğŸŒ Core Concepts

        ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters

        ğŸ”Š AI Summary

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

entries.title: ğŸ« What is Core MBA Courses?
entries.description:
Core MBA Courses form the foundation of business education and are essential for developing analytical and leadership skills.

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

entries.title: ğŸ“ˆ What is MBA Electives?

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

entries.title: ğŸ“Š What is Managerial Economics?
entries.description:
Managerial Economics applies microeconomic theory and quantitative tools to business decision-making.
    
        ğŸ“Š Key Concepts
        - Price elasticity of demand
        - Marginal analysis
        - Game theory and competition
        - Demand forecasting
ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
        This subject equips managers with economic reasoning to optimize production, pricing, and market strategies.
    
        ğŸ“˜ Example Case
        A firm analyzes elasticity to determine whether increasing price will raise revenue or reduce demand too steeply.
    
        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Identify business objective (e.g. maximize profit)
Apply relevant economic model (e.g. demand curve)
Use data to estimate parameters
Simulate outcomes and choose optimal decision

entries.title: ğŸ’¼ What is Organizational Behavior?
entries.description:
Organizational Behavior (OB) studies how individuals, teams, and systems behave in workplace settings.
    
        ğŸ§  Topics Covered
        - Motivation and leadership theories

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters

        ğŸ“˜ Example Case
        A company uses Herzberg's theory to redesign job roles, boosting intrinsic motivation and reducing turnover.
    
        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Diagnose team or individual issue
Select OB framework (e.g. Maslow, Hofstede)
Implement behavioral or cultural intervention
Measure outcomes through engagement metrics

entries.title: ğŸ§  What is Marketing Management?
entries.description:
Marketing Management involves planning, executing, and measuring strategies that deliver value to customers and stakeholders.
    
        ğŸ“¦ Key Areas

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters

        ğŸ“˜ Example Case

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Conduct market research

entries.title: ğŸ“˜ What is Financial Management?
entries.description:
Financial Management teaches how to raise, allocate, and manage funds to optimize firm value.
    
        ğŸ“‰ Key Concepts
        - Time value of money

        - Cost of capital & WACC
        - Risk-return trade-offs
ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters

        ğŸ“˜ Example Case
        A CFO uses discounted cash flow (DCF) analysis to decide whether to acquire a smaller competitor.
    
        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Forecast cash flows
Estimate required return
Apply valuation method (e.g. NPV, IRR)
Choose funding strategy (debt, equity)

entries.title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ What is Operations Management (MBA)?
entries.description:
Operations Management focuses on designing and optimizing processes to deliver goods and services efficiently.

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

entries.title: ğŸ“£ What is Strategic Management?

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

entries.title: ğŸ“¦ What is Entrepreneurship Management?

entries.title: ğŸ“‰ What is Project Management?

entries.title: ğŸŒ What is Supply Chain Management?

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters

entries.title: ğŸ§® What is E-commerce?

entries.title: ğŸ” What is Core Courses (Financial Masters)?

entries.title: ğŸª™ What is Investment?
entries.description:
Investment is the process of allocating capital to financial assets with the goal of earning returns and managing risk.
    
        ğŸ“Š Core Concepts

        ğŸ“˜ Example Case
        Constructing a portfolio with 60% equities and 40% bonds using historical data to backtest performance over the past decade.
    
        ğŸ§­ Workflow

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters

entries.title: ğŸ« What is Corporate Finance?
entries.description:
Corporate Finance studies how firms make decisions about investments, capital structure, and dividends.
    
        ğŸ¢ Key Topics

        ğŸ“˜ Example Case
        A CFO decides whether to finance a $50M expansion via issuing bonds or equity, analyzing EPS dilution and debt ratios.
    
        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Assess financing options and costs
Analyze impact on shareholder value
Monitor performance and risk

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
        Enables optimal use of corporate resources to maximize firm value and strategic growth.

entries.title: ğŸ“ˆ What is Financial Markets?
entries.description:
Financial Markets are systems where individuals and institutions trade financial securities, facilitating capital flow and economic stability.
    
        ğŸŒ Market Types

        ğŸ“˜ Example Case

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

Identify asset classes and instruments

Analyze market microstructure and efficiency

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
        Understanding market mechanics is essential for making informed investment and policy decisions.

entries.title: ğŸ“Š What is Econometrics?

        ğŸ“ˆ Topics

        ğŸ“˜ Example Case

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters

entries.title: ğŸ’¼ What is International Finance?
entries.description:
International Finance deals with the monetary interactions between two or more countries, analyzing exchange rates, capital flows, and global investment.
    
        ğŸŒ Topics
        - Exchange rate systems (fixed, floating)

        ğŸ“˜ Example Case

        ğŸ§­ Workflow

ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
        Critical for managing global portfolios, MNC operations, and responding to geopolitical risks.

entries.title: ğŸ§  What is Financial Risk Management?

        ğŸ“Š Risk Categories

        ğŸ” Application

        - Hedge fund risk control
        - Insurance and pension fund stability
    
        Category: Financial Masters â†’ Risk & Compliance

entries.title: ğŸ“˜ What is Fintech?

entries.title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ What is Mergers and Acquisitions?

entries.title: ğŸ“£ What is Asset Securitization?
entries.description:
Asset Securitization is the process of pooling illiquid assets (like loans or receivables) and converting them into tradable securities.
    
        ğŸ”§ Key Components
        - Originator, Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV), investor

        ğŸ“š Use Cases
        - Mortgage-backed securities (MBS)
        - Collateralized debt obligations (CDOs)
        - Auto loan and credit card receivables securitization
    
        ğŸ’¡ Why It Matters
        - Improves liquidity for financial institutions
        - Distributes risk across investor classes
        - Played a central role in the 2008 global financial crisis
    
        Category: Financial Masters â†’ Advanced Finance
